We use a cyclical approach involving multiple stages to improve the performance of our flood segmentation model. The approach consists of the following steps:

1. Training an ensemble model of multiple U-Net architectures using high-confidence hand-labeled data and generated pseudo labels or low-confidence labels on the entire unlabeled test dataset.
2. Filtering out low-quality generated labels.
3. Combining the generated labels with the previously available high-confidence hand-labeled dataset.
4. Repeating the process until performance improvement plateaus.

We post-process our results using Conditional Random Fields. Our approach sets a new state-of-the-art on the Sentinel-1 dataset with an IoU of 0.7654, outperforming the 0.60 IoU baseline. We release our method, along with all the code and models, as an open science benchmark for the Sentinel-1 dataset.

Introduction:

Flooding events are on the rise due to climate change, resulting in $10 billion worth of damages annually. Scientists and decision-makers can use live Earth observation data from satellites like Sentinel-1 to develop real-time response and mitigation tactics and understand flooding events. The Emerging Techniques in Computational Intelligence (ETCI) 2021 competition on Flood Detection provides SAR Sentinel-1 imagery with labeled pixels for a geographic area prior and post-flood event.

The competition involves a semantic segmentation task that identifies pixels that are flooded and is evaluated using the Intersection over Union metric (IoU). Improved flood segmentation in real-time results in delineating open water flood areas. Identifying flood levels aids in effective disaster response and mitigation. Combining flood extent mapping with local topography generates a plan of action with downstream results, including predicting the direction of water flow, redirecting flood waters, and organizing resources for distribution.

Our system can also recommend a path of least flood levels in real-time that disaster response professionals can adopt.

Equal contribution: Sayak focused on the implementations and contributed to the writing, while Siddha focused on ideation, experimentation, and writing.

Tackling Climate Change with Machine Learning workshop at NeurIPS 2021.

Feature-based machine learning techniques are prominent but are intractable as human annotators and featurizers cannot scale. Manual annotation in real-time can easily exceed $62,500 daily, and a manual solution quickly becomes intractable. Motivated by prior art, we look at semi-supervised techniques that assume predicted labels with maximally predicted probability as ground truth. We apply this to flood segmentation and treat pseudo-labels as an entropy regularizer, which eventually outperforms other conventional methods with a small subset of labeled data.

For real-time deployment, we benchmark our solution similar to [23, 36], which utilize datasets like WorldFloods or multispectral datasets to enable flood detection but require large-scale manual annotation. Contrary to both, our work with semi-supervision reduces the human-in-the-loop load and allows us to take advantage of large unannotated examples in a simple manner.

Evidence indicates that post-processing with Conditional Random Fields (CRF) may yield improved performance, especially for semantic segmentation and satellite data. Our work follows similar lines when we post-process with CRFs for flood segmentation.

Our contributions are:

1. We propose a semi-supervised learning scheme with pseudo-labeling that derives confidence estimates from U-Net ensembles. This establishes the new state-of-the-art flood segmenter, and to the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to try out semi-supervised learning to improve flood segmentation models.
2. We show that our method is scalable through pseudo-labels and generalizable through varying data distributions in different geographic locations, making it inexpensive to deploy scalably.
3. We benchmark the inference pipeline and show that it can be performed in real-time, aiding in real-time disaster mitigation efforts. Our approach also includes uncertainty estimation, allowing disaster response teams to understand its reliability and safety.

In an effort to promote open science and cross-collaboration, we release all our code and models.

The contest dataset consists of 66k tiled images from various geographic locations. Each RGB training tile is generated from VV and VH.
